body:
Some other thoughts:
- Implementation-wise, this is a candidate for residing in libcore. Functionality-wise, I'm not sure if it belongs in libcore.
- The name "time" implies functionality like getting the current time, but the name "duration" is quite long.
- I wouldn't expect the duplication of `foo_ms`, I would expect them all to be deprecated/removed

This is also quite a bold step forward to claim that we have the "one true" Duration type, so we should proceed cautiously. This module, however, seems to be of high quality, so I don't expect that to be too much of a problem.

In general the documentation of this module is pretty scarce, and would be nice to beef up things like the documentation on `Duration`, the module, and cases like why `new` can fail.

> The name "time" implies functionality like getting the current time

Presumably this module can/will become the facade for what is now libtime (i.e. will be extended so that the `time` name fits properly).

Like @alexcrichton, I'm not thrilled about the `foo_ms` functions, I'd rather see them go away (since the names are being reused they can't merely be deprecated).

I'd also like to see a mechanism to convert a `Duration` back into a numeric value with a given period. I see three general approaches that could work here:
1. A bunch of methods, `to_ms()`, `to_ns()`, etc (which would all return signed values).
2. Phantom types for each period (that all implement a trait that provides the conversion between the period and nanoseconds, which would incidentally allow users to define custom periods if that's helpful). This is nice because it could get rid of the plethora of existing constructor methods too, leaving just
   
   ``` rust
   pub fn new<T: Period>(period: T, value: i64) -> Duration;
   pub fn from_parts(days: i32, seconds: u32, nanoseconds: u32) -> Duration;
   ```
   
   Extracting the value would then look like:
   
   ``` rust
   pub fn ticks<T: Period>(&self, period: T) -> i64;
   ```
3. Phantom types for each period again, but make `Duration` be specialized on it instead. This one would be similar to C++'s `std::chrono::duration`. Not sure if there's a compelling reason to do this over approach 2.

I think approach 2 might be the best.

I didn't notice this issue until today, sorry for late replies. Many design issues in rust-chrono are there because I've experimented with different designs (and forgot to revert); feel free to cricitize. As a first step, I've fixed some outstanding issues in rust-chrono.
+1 for remove `days` field and just use `secs: i64, nanos: u32` as @huonw suggested.

I've updated with the latest `Duration` type from rust-chrono. I also removed the `_ms` methods. This addresses _most_ of the feedback.

Some notes:
- I changed `MAX` and `MIN` to `MAX_DURATION` and `MIN_DURATION` since they are in the `time` module, not the `duration` module here.
- Timers need to do something when they see a negative duration. Currently they fail.
- I removed the `zero` constructor since it duplicates `Zero::zero`. This pattern will be fixed at the language level eventually by allowing `Duration::zero` as syntax to call `Zero::zero`.
- The various convenience constructors don't follow conventions (should be `new_seconds` or something).
- The convenience constructors are very verbose. Writing `Duration::milliseconds` feels like torture :)
We might want to put this in `time::duration` and reexport under `time`. That would allow us to keep the `MIN`/`MAX` constants, and leave room for expanding later.

> Timers need to do something when they see a negative duration. Currently they fail.

A timer does not guarantee it will fire at the precise point in time specified by the argument. It will fire in the extremely near future after the given duration has passed. I think that's a good enough justification for treating negative durations as zero, because firing immediately is the best the timer can do to fire at the specified time.

+1 from me as well for removing `days`. It doesn't seem like a particularly noteworthy time division for a duration. Bump `secs` up to `i64` and it should be fine. 292275824290 years ought to be enough for anyone.
Here's the JSR-310 duration: https://github.com/ThreeTen/threetenbp/blob/master/src/main/java/org/threeten/bp/Duration.java. They seem to use i64 secs and (always positive) i32 nanos.

> (always positive) i32 nanos.

(Isn't that mainly because Java has no unsigned types? Not that it matters much if `nanos < 1e9` always.)

Rust-chrono used to have three fields for `Duration` since it's primarily used in relation with `DateTime` and others, and having `days` separate from `secs` is convenient. I agree that this wouldn't be quite useful for this PR though.
Added the examples back.
I'm working on a patch to address timer behavior when duration is zero or negative.
Need to change the `set_timeout` methods on various I/O types to take `Duration`.

In theory the types take an absolute deadline because they should be operating with absolute times, not relative times (see #15802), but they're all experimental for this reason anyway and a duration is certainly better than a `u64`

I've made the three types of timers do something with 0 and negative durations: `sleep` returns immediately and `oneshot` fires the message immediately.

`period` is specced to send a constant stream of messages, but the implementation doesn't actually support this (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/16148) so I added a hack to temporarily use a 1 ms duration in this case. (I'm not sure what this _should_ do with zero duration - sending a torrent of messages in a loop sounds useless to me).

The two `connect_timeout` methods now also take `Duration` and have a precondition that it must be positive (it's impossible to connect instantaneously so a 0 duration is senseless).

Finally, I went ahead and moved `Duration` to `time::duration` so that the constants can stay named `MIN`/`MAX`, and reexported it from `time`.

I have no further edits queued. Need more review.
`connect_timeout` could also just immediately return `Err` on a 0 or negative duration. This might be more inline with the timers that just treat it like an immediate expiration.
I went ahead and made `connect_timeout` return `Err` instead of failing on negative/zero duration because that seems more consistent with the others.
Ready for review.

This generally looks like a good design to me, and I'm happy with the proposed placement into `std::time::duration`. It would definitely benefit from a detailed module-level doc comment, but that can be added separately. 

I don't care much about the _internal_ division into `days`/`secs`/`nanos`, but the choice leaks into the public API in a few places -- the `new` and `new_opt` constructors, and the `to_tuple` function. Since the division is somewhat arbitrary (and not clearly useful to an end-user), I would consider dropping the `new`, `new_opt` and `to_tuple` functions and providing only functions that are independent from the representation here.

Other than these functions, the public API is exactly what I'd expect from any duration type, and I feel comfortable committing to such an API.

Otherwise I have no reservations.

One other comment: I may be very confused, but I don't understand how the various single-unit constructors (`days`, `seconds`, etc) can overflow and fail.

In particular, the `days` constructor calls `to_i32` on a `i32` value, which (afaik...) will always succeed. All of these constructors take `i32` values, which are then modded -- which should place them all within range of the `Duration` type.

But maybe I'm missing something?
A day is not exactly 24 hours! Stores days in duration is a bit weird!
@aturon It looks to me like 'weeks' is the only one that overflows.
@aturon Your points addressed.

I would still like to see `days` removed from the `Duration` struct. It seems to serve no purpose at all. As `num_seconds()` demonstrates, every expressible duration that uses days can be expressed as `i64` seconds instead, and `(seconds, nanoseconds)` is a much more natural representation.
Updated docs per @kballard
Somebody else can change the internal structure.

Perhaps l will, if you don't care.

Rebased and added a FIXME about the representation of `Duration`, with a link to #16466.
OK, looks like all major and many minor comments addressed. Thanks for pushing on this! Let's send it to bors and change the representation in follow-up work.

@brson About the test failure here -- I just landed a patch that checks for deprecation both cross-crate and crate-locally (whereas other stability lints like the unstable lint are checked only cross-crate). This has been turning up various uses of deprecated items. Looks like that's what happened here.
